comments.text:
+Marcin Niedzielski
Yeah, I know. The neck is not made to take that kind of hit...
Luckily, most rear ending are at slow speed ;) And, often, the second chock 
is worst than the first (first hit, got injured... Second hit, make it 
worst).
I'm not saying that it is that much better, though -  an improvement does 
not mean it got to be significant enough.
comments.author: therrydicule

comments.text:
+therrydicule It doesn't matter whether its square or not, serious neck 
injuries account for the vast majority of trauma in any rear collision. 
Good luck thinking it takes a high speed colision to make you a 
quadriplegic.
comments.author: Marcin Niedzielski

comments.text:
+Marcin Niedzielski
When you measure the head-to-chest angle, seat belts seem to reduce 
probability of injuries... Particularly when considering that they are 
always weird angles in real world collision (it's rarely square at the 
back).
The only scenario where quadriplegic could happen is in high speed 
collision, but when it come down to it, the occupants are fucks anyway.
comments.author: therrydicule

comments.text:
+therrydicule If having seatbelts on is going to make you feel better 
about having a snapped neck and either being dead or a quadriplegic than I 
am in no position to tell you otherwise - have at it hoss.
comments.author: Marcin Niedzielski

comments.text:
+Marcin Niedzielski
I was not trying to make a point off, I was just saying that between having 
a rear collision with a seatbelt or one without one... I'm keeping my 
seatbelt on ;)
Of course, I would prefer having none of it, for obvious reasons.
comments.author: therrydicule

comments.text:
+therrydicule My point was seatbelts don't protect you from rear impact, 
you won't become a projectile because you're shoved into the seat not out 
of it when hit from the rear, after that you bounce off  with a fraction of 
the initial force and hit the airbags. I'm sorry not to have made my point 
clearer, forgot its youtube and people with no real arguments get off on 
pointing out technicalities. I'm awaiting for you to start correcting my 
spelling next.
comments.author: Marcin Niedzielski

comments.text:
+Marcin Niedzielski
They still help a bit, in the way that your body would not become some sort 
of projectile and make you hit other structure in the car. Yeah, your neck 
will snap, which is really bad, but it could be worst.
comments.author: therrydicule

comments.text:
+bulletproof12 We should just bring the slaves back if things go the way

You still not answered my question. As i already said many countries manage

and they have a great economy. The higher the wages the more money pump

or thoughts on this matter only benefits the rich. 

Some very small businesses may have issues but the government can have

Every country in the world but 4 including america don't pay maternity 
leave. America just got a health service which is still one of the worse in

guessing you think all of the above is not worthy of improving either then?

comments.author: nabiltherealdeal

comments.text:
If you think low skilled workers won't be affected you are seriously 
retarded. Small businesses won't be able to afford a $15 minimum wage and 
large companies will find a way to offset the cost. Either by mechanization 
or outsourcing. This is already happening in front of your very eyes and 
your head is in the sand.

Your assertion that low skilled workers will still be needed at $15 an hour 
is fucking hilarious and proves to me that you have never studied even the 
first chapter of economics.

If you look at unemployment in the black or hispanic community it's insane. 
Your solution is to make it even harder for these people to get jobs. You 
must really hate minorities sir.
comments.author: bulletproof12

comments.text:
+bulletproof12 Your wrong and extremely ignorant. Your example of Germany 
is wrong. It's €8.50 in euros not dollars which exchanged is nearly $15. 
Switzerland, Sweden and Denmark earn over $20 an hour. The poorer countries 
in Europe don't have great pay but still have a living wage i.e pay the 
bills and get food on the table. 

You obviously a privileged right wing knuckle head. It does not matter if 
employees are untrained or uneducated they still deserve a living wage. I'm 
not suggesting riches but enough to have a roof over their head and food to 
survive. 

It should be down to the government to enforce this rather than walmart. 
Walmart however should have the common decency to do this. Many companies 
won't go over seas . Products are already produced overseas anyway so be no 
difference there. Many low skilled workers won't lose their jobs because 
they would still be needed. 

If Walmart shared a fraction of their annual billions they would easily 
cover the minimum wage. What have you got against massive companies sharing 
their profits?

You sir are a fool
comments.author: nabiltherealdeal

comments.text:
+nabiltherealdeal Well color me surprised another person saying how the 
world "should" work and not understanding the real world. People who work 
in Walmart are untrained, uneducated employees who lack any technical 
skills whatsoever. If they did they would earn a better income from another 
employer. 

Europe doesn't have a minimum wage, the countries all have their own 
standard. So there is your first idiotic statement.

Secondly, most of European countries are under water in debt, with Germany 
being one of the few exceptions. Germany just recently proposed a minimum 
wage of around $8.50 an hour. That's hardly a living wage, and they will 
pay for it in the long run. You comparing us to Europe, which is made of 
many countries with different leadership is a joke really. What country 
specifically are you comparing us to who have this magnificent "living" 
wage?

Thirdly, you liberals love to say "raise the minimum wage" but fail to 
comprehend that if minimum wage is $12-20 an hour, many low skilled workers 
will lose their jobs and more companies will go overseas. 

I don't expect much from TYT viewers but I must say you lowered my bar. :)

top_comment.text:
I think TYT is wrong here with the driver.  Walmart can't force anyone to 
drive over their hours.  Walmart can't force a driver to go 24-36 hour 
shifts and they use electronic logs so you cant even violate your log book. 
 Nobody knows what the driver was doing in his off time, or why he was up 
that long, but blaming Walmart for what the driver does is just passing the 
buck.

Let's put it this way, if a driver says 'sorry my log book is up' and 
walmart said 'do this or else your fired' then walmart is in serious 
trouble.  The guy walks, goes home, gets unemployment and a fat lawsuit 
check.﻿
top_comment.author: worldgate989

comments.text: Yup Fuck walmart
comments.author: Trent Meade

comments.text:
+Daniel Stone You have the same long winded 'honest it wasn't my fault' 
story everyone has.  Walmart can't force people to do something they can't

comments.author: worldgate989

comments.text:
+mike Walker The average Wal Mart truck driver makes over 75k a year man... 
Truck drivers are a really limited commodity, the market is super tight.
comments.author: volcombillx3

comments.text:
All corporate entities are responsible for what their employees do with 
their equipment and yes, they can and do regularly force employees to work 
above and beyond what is reasonable just to keep prices low and profits 
high . If you doubt this just look at how they handled the deaths involved 
with those Bangladesh garment factory fires .
comments.author: Jason  Hare

comments.text:
+worldgate989 yes they can.  especially If you are unlucky enough to live 
in a so called "right to work" state, which really means "we have the right 
to fire you for any reason."  I worked there for 7 years and they fired me 
for refusing to work past my shift which they regularly demanded and that 
day I just couldn't do it.  You are correct about the unemployment which 
they declined and fought to keep me from getting.  When I went to the state 
though they decided that since I had never been disciplined in 7 years, 
showed no pattern of insubordination, and they were asking me to work past 
my scheduled shift they shouldn't have fired me and i got my unemployment. 
They threaten people with firing because they know it scares people.  They 
know their employees are living week to week and the prospect of being 
fired is terrifying.  I knew other people over the years who had gotten 
fired for nonsense and unfortunately just accepted it when their 
unemployment was denied, not realizing they could or not wanting to deal 
with fighting for it. 

Also don't think that when they were asking people to work over their shift 
it meant we were getting over time.  we weren't.  As soon as you hit 40 
hours they would come and tell you to go home.  Which lead to work not 
getting done, which lead to other people having to stay past their shifts. 
 Nothing like going to work everyday (or night I was 3rd shift) and not 
knowing when you were going to get to go home and being strong-armed with 
threats if you had to go home when your shift was actually supposed to end. 
 It just created an entire shift of people who would pretty much rather die 
than come to work. You could cut the negative vibe in that place with a 
knife every night.

Oh I almost forgot the whole story.  They added to my exit form after I 
signed it.  They made up a story that I yelled and cursed and even tried to 
start a physical fight with management.  Which was totally false and I 
obviously wouldn't have signed the exit had their little fiction been 
there. During the hearing I was able to prove it was a lie because the 
management who testified to this couldn't keep their story straight when I 
was able to question them about it.  It was pretty comical the adjudicator 
was pretty sicked by them.

Now this is just anecdotal evidence.  Im just one person who worked with a 
group of people at one store.  I cant speak for every walmart employee, but 
this was my experience.

In the end though if the driver was on walmarts clock they are liable.
comments.author: Daniel Stone

comments.text: +Chad Stewart sarcasm not appreciated sir
comments.author: worldgate989

comments.text:
I agree with your point. This is were TYT is very ignorant in their 
broadcasting of the opinions.
comments.author: Chad Stewart

comments.text:
+takanara7 I have driven for walmart and they were nothing but cool.  They 
always ask if you can make a load and if you cant they take it off.  If you 
can make it on time, you return when you are legal to do so.  The driver 
was doing something he shouldnt be doing, ie not resting.
comments.author: worldgate989

comments.text:
+turtle79070 No, they can't.  You can't fire a driver because they could 
not make it back in time.  Thats why we have sleeper cabs.  First it's a 
hostile work environment, second it violates the regulations of illegal 
dispatch.
comments.author: worldgate989

comments.text:
sure they cant force you to drive that long but they can say "hey if your 
not here by this time and go back by this time your fired"
comments.author: turtle79070

comments.text:
> I think TYT is wrong here with the driver.  Walmart can't force anyone to 
drive over their hours.

They can, however, force drivers NOT to drive over their hours.  Their 
failure to do so makes them liable.

I mean, the catholic church can't FORCE priests not to molest children 
either.  But they're supposed to *make an effort* to prevent it from 
happening.  If not, they can be found legally liable.

> Of course i expect no response from TYT, they never acknowledge when 
their wrong.﻿

Just because you don't understand how the law works doesn't make TYT 
"wrong".  You might personally feel WM isn't "at fault" but that's just 
your opinion.  Opinions aren't wrong or right. They're opinions. The law 
sides with them in this case, though.

On the other hand, they do get facts wrong.  Like in one of their videos 
they said Vinod Khosla  was Russian.  The guy is Indian. That's a basic 
fact that they never did a retraction about.
comments.author: takanara7

comments.text:

leaches from communities and doesn't contribute as much as people think.

provide produces to Walmart at a reduced price. The manufacturer cuts back

for their produces. That is why their clothing,etc, is of such poor quality.

top_comment.text:
A question for people in the US. Are there any laws regulating bus/truck 
drivers?

I ask, because where I live each bus/truck driver has a personal "black 
box" which records how much and for how long they drive. Those a regularly 
checked against company logistic plans, they also spot check them in random 
traffic stops. Company can get huge fines if they overwork the drivers.﻿
top_comment.author: - KoperKat

comments.text:
Oh, I just find it weird it didn't get mentioned. A schedule like that 
would make the company liable for criminal charges on public endangerment. 
It would also be relevant in a civil court case.
comments.author: - KoperKat

comments.text:
there are laws regulating truck drivers, its a different thing entirely if 
said laws are followed by the companies.
comments.author: DaHuntsman1

top_comment.text:
Well, what did Walmart say wrong here? It's fashionable to hate them but i 
can see their point here. If they were wearing seat belts their injuries 
would have been much smaller and the person who died could still be alive. 
They should face consequences for overworking their drivers but the people 
in the car are not fully blameless either - if you refuse to wear a seat 
belt then you have to take part of the blame too.﻿
top_comment.author: Nikolay Ivanov

comments.text:
You know, there's the whole "not being thrown around inside the car like a 
rag doll, or getting thrown out the window" part when you use a seat belt. 
I know it's not "cool" to sit with a seat belt in a party limo but that's 
the harsh truth. It's very likely Walmart will have have a much more 
lenient sentence because of that, it's the same with every other car 
accident where seat belts were not used.
comments.author: Nikolay Ivanov

+Eduardo Alfonso If a truck goes 65 and the car in front 35, then the

that case.

+sprybug Well, you see, that's the problem with capitalism. To produce 
anything of highest possible quality is no good, because, that means less 
profit for someone else.

To produce in less quality=more waste, for obvious reasons.

I recommend that you watch "Zeitgeist: Moving Forward".
comments.author: Homo Sapien 78

comments.text:
+Homo Sapien 78 Are you serious?  Do I have to give you examples to figure 
this out?  Really?  Alright, I guess I do.  You have a plant that produces 
some shit, I don't know, anything you can think of and a piece of machinery 
constantly breaks down, halting production, costing you money.  Well, if 
you spent the money to fix that thing so it no longer breaks down (or just 
get a new one), in time you will actually make money because you're no 
longer losing money due to lost time and lost production.  Okay, now you 
get it?

actually work.  A lot of that does go on, but not usually when it comes to 
defendants paying for personal injuries they cause.

Not wearing seatbelts generally means the injuries in a crash are worse 
than they would otherwise. General logic being "I did my best to control 
the crash safely, but you went through the windshield anyway because you 
were breaking the law." Crash is on walmart, but if a seatbelt could have 
made the difference between life & death...
It's probably going to end in a somewhat reasonable compromise unless 
they're stupid and try to fight corporate lawyers for all the marbles.﻿

comments.author: Bill Norton

comments.text:
+Bill Norton
There is a double edged sword to that though because the current proposed 
"reform" would only benefit business and not the public. It wouldnt change 
the "nature of the best" so to speak and that, in my view, is what needs to 
be changed *first.*

When regulation towards business is more responsible from the get go 
instead of just viewed towards what they can get away with and what is 
"cost effective" then having those proposed reforms will only increase 
their bad behavior because it will then be even more cost effective.

captions.text: >> ANA: Back in June, Tracy Morgan was involved in a car accident,
where a Walmart truck driver rear ended a limousine that he was in with his friends.
As a result, he's suffered from serious injuries that forced him to go into rehab.
He had injuries to his ribs and his legs.
And one of his friends, James McNair, died as a result of the car accident.
Well, now Tracy Morgan has filed a lawsuit against Walmart,
because of the fact that the driver was behind the wheel for too long.
He was speeding, and there was obviously some wrongdoing on his part.
And so what's interesting is Walmart's response to it.
So let me give you the details of what the lawsuit says.
And then I'll tell you what Walmart had to say in response.
So Walmart responds by saying that the passengers' injuries were caused in whole or in part by their failure
to properly wear an appropriate seat belt restraint device.
That is unbelievable.
And they say that that constitutes unreasonable conduct. .
>> CENK: Okay.
Now, I know why Walmart's saying.
It's a legal defense that's fairly common where they say,
it's not completely our fault.
You contributed to the issue at hand here.
So we should not be wholly responsible.
We should at most be partly responsible.
Now, I understand that in the legal world.
Now, having said that, it looks really, really bad.
I mean, you saw that limo, man.
They tore that thing apart.
And the guy inside died, let alone what happened to Tracy Morgan.
And to looks incredibly callus to then turn around and say,
yeah, our driver was driving for 13 and a half straight hours.
And he had been up for over 24 hours.  And yes, your friend died.
And you suffered terrible injuries.
But it was your fault.
>> ANA: You weren't wearing a seat belt.
You know, there is possibly an interesting loophole in the seat belt law.
I don't know if this loophole exists.
But I find it strange that when it comes to limos, a lot of them don't have seat belts.
The same for buses.
A lot of buses don't have seat belts either.
So I don't know why that's allowed to happen.
If we have seat belt laws on the books.
But it might not even have been their fault and they weren't wearing a seat belt.
>> CENK: Yeah.
So now, look.
I think Walmart's all wrong.
One, because it seems despicable and cold-hearted.
Two, it's terrible public policy.
I mean, they're image is hurt by this, because the guy's famous.
you see what I mean you see what I'm saying look, they crush little people all the time.
They don't care, and they're not gonna get called out on it.
But in this case, I mean, even if you disagree with how much they're asking for,
you got to make it go away.
I think it's a really stupid PR on their fault on their part, I should say.
Now, when it gets to the real fault at hand, so you enjoy their low cost at Walmart.
And oh, my God, I got this for a couple cents cheaper.
But that's partly because they push the boundaries and paths the boundaries.
And can I get this guy to drive for 13 hours, forty hours,
14 hours, 15 hours so I could milk as much as I can out of that guy before I have to pay another guy, etc..
And sometimes when you do that, it has consequences.
And in this case, the consequences were lethal.
>> ANA: I think that the really big issue here is the fact that we regulate companies like Walmart too much.
So for instance, when it comes to these truck drivers, they're not supposed to to be behind the wheel for
more than 11 hours.
Now, if we did away with that regulation, obviously Walmart would make their drivers drive the right amount of times
so these accidents don't occur.
>> CENK: What's interesting is that they don't make them drive less than 11 hours.
They push it all the way to the edge.
And beyond the edge anyway.
If you took away the regulation, they would push even further out.
And then they would say oh, that's okay.
We have these 18 wheelers smashing into cars on the highways all across the country.
Then people got mad and hence some of them didn't go to Walmart.
Free market.
That's not how it's supposed to work and it's certainly not how you would want it to work.
It was your family member that that 18 wheeler crashed into.
>> ANA: I don't think Walmart really cares about bad PR at this point.
I mean, every time Walmart is in the headlines, it's for something negative.
Very rarely has Walmart been in the headlines because they treat their employees
or because they care about their image, so they're doing things to fix the situations that they're coping with.
You know what I mean?
It's always something negative.
And they don't change anything.
They don't want unionized workers.
They don't want to pay their employees more.
Negative headline after negative headline doesn't matter.
They keep their policies the same.
>> CENK:  it reminds me of this amazing fact.
Did you know that the six heirs to the Walmart fortune --
Sam Walton was the founder.
The six heirs did not -- they found a lot of money.
But they did not found Walmart.
So they just got lucky by an accident of birth.
Those six people have more money than the bottom 100 million Americans combined.
>> ANA: That's amazing.
>> CENK: 100 million Americans.
So their attitude is probably like, whatever.
>> ANA: Exactly.
>> CENK: Who cares?
I already got paid, man.
>> ANA: That's absolutely right.
>> CENK: Now, I know Walmart is not run by the heirs.
But there is an attitude that trickles down to management where they're like,
hey, keep the prices low and keep it rolling.
Who cares what the consequences are?

title: Walmart To Tracy Morgan: You're Partly To Blame For The Crash
